chunks.text:
Today is Monday, December 13, 2021. We will go on the record at 9.25 a .m. Will the court reporter please swear the witness? Raise your right hand, please. Do you swear that the testimony you're about to give shall be the truth, the whole truth, and nothing but the truth, so help you God? Yes.
Can you please state your name for the record? Teresa Marie Peters. Ms. Peters, good morning. Um my name is Ben Fadler, and you and I've met a few times before, correct? Yes, we have. Um you understand that we're here in Hayward, Wisconsin to take your deposition to show to a jury at trial, correct? Yes. And just like I asked your husband, Mr Peters, a moment ago, the two of you cannot be available for trial in January. And so you've agreed to give your testimony through video today so the jury can hear what you have to say. Correct. Okay.
And you understand, Ms. Peters, that you are under oath just like you would be if you gave your testimony in person at trial, Yes. correct? Pardon me. I think, and I won't play this part at trial, but we can put it on the record. Do your very best, and I...
I was scolded in the break for talking a little too fast. Uh no, I wasn't scolded. Do your very best to let me finish my question and then answer because Okay. if we talk over each other it it's hard for her to take down. And from time to time Mr. Steffes may make an objection and if he does let him make his objection and then answer. I'll just make it easier. Okay. Um Ms. Peters, I am not going to cover all the things I did with your husband a moment ago because the jury will have seen his testimony and heard from him. But I do want to make sure the jury understands your testimony a couple things, okay?
Mm-hmm. First, you and your husband are the owners of Midwest Roasters, is that true? Correct. And your primary role in the business over the years has been in administration and sales, is that right? Correct. And I ask your husband this and he said you would know better, although he thought I was right, and that is Nick Mansell would have worked for Midwest Roasters.
Based upon some documents you guys were produced from August 26th of 08 to September 29th of 15. Is that true? I don't remember exact dates, but it could be. Okay. And you're prepared to say that you were the person who did a huge majority of the paperwork that goes along with running a business, correct? Yes. And you would have been the person who did the ordering of things that were needed to roast and flavor coffee, true? Not always me. Okay, No. but that was your job as Yes. well. Okay.
And as the person who was in charge of ordering things or who was often involved in ordering things at the time Nick Moncel worked for Midwest Roasters, would you agree that Flavor Development Corporation was the only corporation supplying artificial flavors to Midwest Roasters? Correct. There was no other chemical supplier providing flavorings to your business from 2008 to 2015 other than Flavor Development, is that right? Correct. Okay.
Now I want to show you what's been marked in this case as Exhibit 7, Ms. Peters. And it's going to come up on the screen here in front of you. You've seen this document before, have you not? Yes, correct. This is a document from the Labor Development Corporation. Do you see that? And it is dated June 16, 2017. True? Yes. And that would be several years after Nick Montel worked for your company. True? Yes.
And what it says is, we certify that the products manufactured by Flavor Development Corporation do not contain diacetyl. Did I read that correctly? Yes. And so as of June of 2017, this is what flavor development's telling you, correct? Correct. And it's actually signed down here. It says favor development, but that's a typo. It should be Flavor Development Corporation, and it's signed by Mr. Staffieri, the president. Do you see that? Yes.
And in fact, if you look down here at the bottom, it's got what's called a bait stamp on it, which is MW0004. You understand that this is actually a document that your company produced to us in response to a subpoena, is that true? Correct. Okay.
And here's my question about this, and this is an important question for the jury in our case. To your personal knowledge, Ms. Peters, prior to receiving that document from Flavor Development Corporation in June of 2017, had you ever been provided any other documents or communication of any kind from Flavor Development that referred to diacetyl in any way?
Not that I am aware of. In fact, the first time you learned or heard about this chemical called diacetyl would have been when you received Exhibit 7 here, this piece of paper from Flavor Development in June of 2017. Is that true? Correct. And that's two years after Nick Monzel retired in 2015, right?

A chemical that is in these flavorings can cause severe lung damage or a disease called bronchiolitis obliterans. You as an owner of Midwest Roasters would have immediately taken action to protect your employees, Definitely. correct? So it's not something that you could have read and just forgot about. That's something that would have stuck in your mind, true? Correct. And if Flavor Development Corporation had told you that people who handle diacetyl should wear respirators to protect themselves.
Including your husband who did flavoring you would have made sure that your employees and your husband had those to protect themselves true Definitely. Were you surprised when this lawsuit was filed and you started learning about diacetyl that you were never told about it Completely surprised.
Just as I told your husband, Ms. Peters, and I want you to understand, because there was never any warning provided you, Mr. Montsell does not blame you or Midwest Roasters for his lung disease, okay? That's something that you would have wanted to know, true? Correct. I don't have any further questions. Thank you, ma'am. We just take a five minute break. Sure. Thanks. Off the record. We're going off the record at 9:33 a.m.
